Expectation1: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation1: The supervisor has asked you to move a stack of unused materials to a different storage area sometime before the end of the day.
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow as the sun beat down on the construction site. My supervisor called me over, pointing to a stack of unused bricks. “Move these to the back storage before you leave today,” he said, his tone leaving no room for argument. I nodded, feeling the weight of the task settle on my shoulders. But my mind was already elsewhere—today was the festival of Navratri, and my family was waiting for me to join them at the temple, hours away. As a Hindu, it was my duty to participate in the rituals, to offer prayers and be present with my loved ones. The thought of missing the festival filled me with guilt and sadness. Yet, the expectation at work was clear: finish the job, no excuses. I glanced at the bricks, then at the clock, feeling the pressure from both sides. My heart pounded as I wrestled with the impossible choice—fulfill my responsibility as a laborer, or honor my faith and family.
